title: Creating individuals
text: physiology individual defined values simulation parameters. simulate specific individual, one generate set parameter values apply values model. NOTE: Currently, individuals species original *.pkml simulation can applied. .e., simulation exported PK-Sim represents human individual, possible simulate another human individual different race, gender, etc., possible simulate rat. Though technically possible, simulation produce results, valid. first step creating object describing individual characteristics. see list available values arguments species, population (human), gender (human), use enums Species, HumanPopulation, Gender, respectively. object passed function createIndividual generate set parameter values. algorithm behind used PK-Sim creating Individual-Building Block. output contains two lists parameters: distributedParameters: parameters differ individuals selected species derivedParameters: parameters defined formulas simulation applying generated individual parameter set simulation R, parameters distributedParameters overwritten, otherwise formula dependencies may destroyed. Generated parameter values can conveniently applied using setParameterValuesByPath method:
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # If no unit is specified, the default units are used. For "weight" it is "kg", for "age" it is "year(s)". individualCharacteristics <- createIndividualCharacteristics(   species    = Species$Human,   population = HumanPopulation$Japanese_Population,   gender     = Gender$Female,   weight     = 75,   height     = 1.75,   heightUnit = "m",   age        = 43 ) print(individualCharacteristics) #> IndividualCharacteristics:  #>    Species: Human  #>    Population: Japanese_Population  #>    Gender: FEMALE  #>    Age: 43.00 [year(s)]  #>    Gestational age: 40.00 [week(s)]  #>    Weight: 75.00 [kg]  #>    Height: 1.75 [m]  individual <- createIndividual(individualCharacteristics = individualCharacteristics)  # we will not be printing this given the long length of the output, but you can # see the details by running: # print(individual) library(ospsuite)  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") print(simFilePath) #> [1] "C:/Users/IndrajeetPatil/Documents/R/win-library/4.1/ospsuite/extdata/Aciclovir.pkml" sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Apply individual parameters setParameterValuesByPath(   parameterPaths = individual$distributedParameters$paths,   values         = individual$distributedParameters$values,   simulation     = sim )

title: Creating individuals
text: PK-Sim database includes ontogeny information proteins (see (PK-Sim Ontogeny Database)[https://github.com/Open-Systems-Pharmacology/OSPSuite.Documentation/blob/master/PK-Sim%20Ontogeny%20Database%20Version%207.3.pdf]). protein molecule present simulation, possible add ontogeny information one pre-defined proteins. example, possible set ontogeny protein MyProtein value ontogeny CYP3A4 enzyme specified individual. list supported ontogenies stored StandardOntogeny-list.
code: library(ospsuite)  # All supported ontogenies print(StandardOntogeny) #> $CYP1A2 #> [1] "CYP1A2" #>  #> $CYP2C18 #> [1] "CYP2C18" #>  #> $CYP2C19 #> [1] "CYP2C19" #>  #> $CYP2C8 #> [1] "CYP2C8" #>  #> $CYP2C9 #> [1] "CYP2C9" #>  #> $CYP2D6 #> [1] "CYP2D6" #>  #> $CYP2E1 #> [1] "CYP2E1" #>  #> $CYP3A4 #> [1] "CYP3A4" #>  #> $CYP3A5 #> [1] "CYP3A5" #>  #> $CYP3A7 #> [1] "CYP3A7" #>  #> $UGT1A1 #> [1] "UGT1A1" #>  #> $UGT1A4 #> [1] "UGT1A4" #>  #> $UGT1A6 #> [1] "UGT1A6" #>  #> $UGT1A9 #> [1] "UGT1A9" #>  #> $UGT2B4 #> [1] "UGT2B4" #>  #> $UGT2B7 #> [1] "UGT2B7"  # Create the ontogeny for the protein "MyProtein" based on ontology of CYP3A4 myProteinOntogeny <- MoleculeOntogeny$new(molecule = "MyProtein", ontogeny = StandardOntogeny$CYP3A4) print(myProteinOntogeny) #> MoleculeOntogeny:  #>    Molecule: MyProtein  #>    Ontogeny: CYP3A4  # Add this ontogeny to the individual characteristics used to create the individual parameters set individualCharacterstics <- createIndividualCharacteristics(   species            = Species$Human,   population         = HumanPopulation$Japanese_Population,   gender             = Gender$Female,   weight             = 75,   height             = 1.75,   heightUnit         = "m",   age                = 43,   moleculeOntogenies = myProteinOntogeny ) print(individualCharacterstics) #> IndividualCharacteristics:  #>    Species: Human  #>    Population: Japanese_Population  #>    Gender: FEMALE  #>    Age: 43.00 [year(s)]  #>    Gestational age: 40.00 [week(s)]  #>    Weight: 75.00 [kg]  #>    Height: 1.75 [m]  #>    Molecule MyProtein with ontogeny CYP3A4:  individual <- createIndividual(individualCharacteristics = individualCharacterstics)

title: Population simulations
text: Population simulations can easily performed R combining simulation loaded *.pkml file population information created PK-Sim exported CSV format (details, please refer OSPS online documentation) created directly R (see Creating populations).

title: Population simulations
text: method loadPopulation creates object Population class can passed runSimulation() method (see Running simulations retrieving results).
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000 # Load population information from csv popFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "pop.csv", package = "ospsuite") myPopulation <- loadPopulation(csvPopulationFile = popFilePath) print(myPopulation) #> Population:  #>    Number of Individuals: 10

title: Population simulations
text: Similar creating individual parameter sets (see Creating individuals), population created population characteristics created calling method createPopulationCharacteristics(). see list available values arguments species population (human), use enums Species HumanPopulation, respectively. returned object type PopulationCharacteristics passed function createPopulation generate set parameter values. algorithm behind used PK-Sim creating population. Molecule ontogenies can added described vignette Creating individuals.
code: library(ospsuite)  # If no unit is specified, the default units are used. For "height" it is "dm", for "weight" it is "kg", for "age" it is "year(s)". populationCharacteristics <- createPopulationCharacteristics(   species             = Species$Human,   population          = HumanPopulation$Asian_Tanaka_1996,   numberOfIndividuals = 50,   proportionOfFemales = 50,   weightMin           = 30,   weightMax           = 98,   weightUnit          = "kg",   heightMin           = NULL,   heightMax           = NULL,   ageMin              = 0,   ageMax              = 80,   ageUnit             = "year(s)" ) print(populationCharacteristics) #> PopulationCharacteristics:  #>    Species: Human  #>    Population: Asian_Tanaka_1996  #>    Number of individuals: 50  #>    Proportion of females: 50  #>    Age: [0.00 year(s)..80.00 year(s)]  #>    Gestational age: ]-Inf..+Inf[  #>    Weight: [30.00 kg..98.00 kg]  #>    Height: ]-Inf..+Inf[  #>    BMI: ]-Inf..+Inf[  # Create population from population characteristics result <- createPopulation(populationCharacteristics = populationCharacteristics) myPopulation <- result$population print(myPopulation) #> Population:  #>    Number of Individuals: 50

title: Population simulations
text: run population simulation, Population object created createPopulation method must passed runSimulation() method: Population simulations run parallel multi-core machines - one core simulates subset individuals defined population. default, number cores used equals maximal number logical cores available minus one. user can change default behavior providing custom SimulationRunOptions(). Simulated time-value pairs specific output SimulationResults-object returned runSimulation method can accessed method getOutputValues. user can provide either path(s) output (can molecule, parameter, observer), object(s) type Molecule, Parameter, Quantity (observers) argument quantitiesOrPaths. output specified, outputs available simulation results returned. paths available outputs can accessed via getOutputValues() returns list two entries: data metadata: IndividualId Time vector simulated time values (minutes, equal outputs) vector simulated entries output requested. values IndividualId, Time, simulated outputs, appended simulated individual. Note results non-monotonously increasing column Time.  get results specific individual set individuals, argument individualIds method getOutputValues() can specified:  information running simulations, please refer Running simulations retrieving results.
code: library(ospsuite)  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Run population simulation simulationResults <- runSimulation(simulation = sim, population = myPopulation) print(simulationResults) #> SimulationResults:  #>    Number of individuals: 50 # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Create a SimulationRunOptions object simRunOptions <- SimulationRunOptions$new() print(simRunOptions) #> SimulationRunOptions:  #>    numberOfCores: 15  #>    checkForNegativeValues: TRUE  #>    showProgress: FALSE  # Change the maximal number of cores to use and show a progress bar during simulation simRunOptions$numberOfCores <- 3 simRunOptions$showProgress <- TRUE  # Run population simulation with custom options populationResults <- runSimulation(simulation = sim, population = myPopulation, simulationRunOptions = simRunOptions) print(populationResults) #> SimulationResults:  #>    Number of individuals: 50 populationResults$allQuantityPaths #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)" # Get simulated results by path resultsPath <- populationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(resultsPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  resultsData <- getOutputValues(populationResults, quantitiesOrPaths = resultsPath)  resultsTime <- resultsData$data$Time resultsValues <- resultsData$data$`Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)`  plot(resultsTime, resultsValues, type = "l") # Get simulated results by path resultsPath <- populationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(resultsPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  # Get only the results for individuals with IDs 1 and 2 resultsData <- getOutputValues(populationResults, quantitiesOrPaths = resultsPath, individualIds = c(1, 2))  resultsTime <- resultsData$data$Time resultsValues <- resultsData$data$`Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)`  plot(resultsTime, resultsValues, type = "l")

what: Life cycle of a simulation run
title: Efficient calculation
text: general, user loads simulation, updates parameter values, calculates simulation retrieves results. steps inherent simulation: Loading simulation Optional: Setting parameter values Optional: Setting initial values Initializing simulation engine Solving ODE System (calculating outputs) Depending simulation interest, steps might take much longer others. example, simulation multiple administrations simulated many months load initialize quickly (1 4) calculating (5) critical step. hand, simulation dozens compounds also take time load initialize (1 4).

title: Efficient calculation
text: far easiest use cases. simulation loaded .pkml file outputs calculated. use case, step 4 5 automatically lumped together one single call (See Run Simulations details).

what: Running a single simulation multiple times and varying some parameters/initial values between each run
title: Efficient calculation
text: already use case optimal efficient way depends drastically simulation hand. Let’s assume want calculate outputs simulation different doses. simple implementation follow following idea, simulation loaded , dose value updated simulation calculated dose interest. implementation fairly easy understand, potentially one big performance bottleneck. simulation run performed sequentially (.e. one time). means performance boost multiple cores machine. simulation takes seconds run, solution absolutely acceptable. However, assume simulation takes 1h run, code take 5h complete, runSimulations call executed sequentially. simulation run time (5) much greater loading (1) initialization time (4), better approach load simulation multiple times run simulation concurrently (.e. parallel). Consider following implementation: implementation also fairly straight forward. load simulation multiple times file (note usage loadFromCache = FALSE ensure always get new instance simulation instance) set dose. , call runSimulations function list simulations. engine run simulations parallel, means overall execution time slightly 1h, run executed time.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) doseParameter <- getAllParametersMatching(toPathString("Applications", "**", "Dose"), sim)[[1]]  # run for dose 100mg doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, 100, "mg") result100 <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)  # run for dose 200mg doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, 200, "mg") result200 <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)  # ...  # run for dose 500mg doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, 500, "mg") result500 <- runSimulations(simulations = sim) library(ospsuite) # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  loadSimulationWithDose <- function(doseInMg) {   sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath, loadFromCache = FALSE)   doseParameter <- getAllParametersMatching(toPathString("Applications", "**", "Dose"), sim)[[1]]   doseParameter$value <- toBaseUnit(doseParameter, doseInMg, "mg")   return(sim) }  # Creates 5 instances of a simulation (This is very fast for typical simulations) sim100 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 100) sim200 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 200) sim300 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 300) sim400 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 400) sim500 <- loadSimulationWithDose(doseInMg = 500)   # Runs the simulation in parallel results <- runSimulations(simulations = list(sim100, sim200, sim300, sim400, sim500))  # Results in now a list of SimulationResults

what: Optimized loading for running simulations with pre-defined set of variable parameters
title: Efficient calculation
text: advanced use case, typically implementing kind optimization sensitivity algorithms. ospsuite package introduces concept simulation batch. simulation batch, variable parameters (initial values) simulation vary run specified explicitly creation simulation batch. allows simulation engine speed system significantly equations can rewritten simplified. simulation batch also keeps simplified simulation memory. means running simulation new set values much faster, initialization phase (4) done required every run. Consider following implementation. first create two simulation batches model define parameter values can changed runs. Note , opposed Simulation object, access parameter/species values can change outputs simulation time. next step, define multiple runs simulation batch adding different parameter (/species start) values set. set values correspond one run. benefit approach initialization steps (1 4) performed . , execution time (step 5) impact total performance. far, created 2 simulation batches, one 3 parameter sets one 4. means 3 runs enqueued simBatch1 4 enqueued simBatch2. run gets unique id can later used correctly assign simulation results simulated set parameters. enqueued run values cleared calling runSimulationBatches(), executing run result empty results list. can now set values batches run . Notes: - always set number values time - Previous runValues automatically cleared runSimulationBatches() called. Usage SimulationBatch recommended advanced scenarios simulations expected run hundreds times second can spared impact performance significantly.
code: library(ospsuite) simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  # We load the simulation for which the batches will be created sim1 <- loadSimulation(simFilePath, loadFromCache = FALSE)  # define the list of parameter that will be varied between the runs. # For the first batch, we will vary 2 parameters: Lipophilicity and Permeability parameterPaths <- c("Aciclovir|Lipophilicity", "Aciclovir|Permeability")  # define a first simulation batch simBatch1 <- createSimulationBatch(simulation = sim1, parametersOrPaths = parameterPaths)  # for the second batch, we will vary Molecular Weight simBatch2 <- createSimulationBatch(   simulation = sim1,   parametersOrPaths = c("Aciclovir|Molecular weight") )  simulationBatches <- list(simBatch1, simBatch2) # now setting some parameter run values (the size of the array should match # the number of parameters to vary for each batch simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(1, 2)) #> [1] "a1efcbb7-cae7-4d06-b19c-017de92446f9" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(3, 4)) #> [1] "d6d6db5f-0429-4c00-a637-f4c1e98dca96" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(5, 6)) #> [1] "4b5c2802-ac7e-4c6f-a075-0e6923694496"  # We only have one parameter to vary for simBatch2, therefore only one value to set simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 150) #> [1] "6a4f8272-89fd-40d0-b418-b59a2b0b29a9" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 200) #> [1] "09c4e100-70aa-4d59-962a-b9bae894c5fa" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 300) #> [1] "e0f9a862-2179-47d1-9361-4120e09c31b1" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 400) #> [1] "b040218c-f295-4934-8a27-7d7337b6b4e7" # Now we run the simulation batches. # By doing so, 7 runs (3 for simBatch1 and 4 for simBatch2) will be executed in parallel. # Please see documentation of runSimulationBatches for more details. # The resulting output is a named list, where the names are the ids of the enqueued runs. results <- runSimulationBatches(simulationBatches) print(names(unlist(results))) #> [1] "a1efcbb7-cae7-4d06-b19c-017de92446f9" #> [2] "d6d6db5f-0429-4c00-a637-f4c1e98dca96" #> [3] "4b5c2802-ac7e-4c6f-a075-0e6923694496" #> [4] "6a4f8272-89fd-40d0-b418-b59a2b0b29a9" #> [5] "09c4e100-70aa-4d59-962a-b9bae894c5fa" #> [6] "e0f9a862-2179-47d1-9361-4120e09c31b1" #> [7] "b040218c-f295-4934-8a27-7d7337b6b4e7" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(10, 20)) #> [1] "fa2877ea-039e-4721-8088-c02e244c270f" simBatch1$addRunValues(parameterValues = c(30, 40)) #> [1] "844ea336-5ff5-44e8-919a-ecc0f62231ba" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 500) #> [1] "37663836-4f31-482a-828c-3ef350023ce1" simBatch2$addRunValues(parameterValues = 200) #> [1] "6bcb58c1-3980-4b42-9c1a-132f616dcdaf"  # this run will be much faster as the simulation won't be initialized again. # Only the new value will be set as specified when adding new run values with addRunValues results2 <- runSimulationBatches(simulationBatches)  # Once the simulation batches instances are not needed anymore, they can be removed # from the environment and the allocated memory cleared. # This will be done automatically when the R session is terminated. rm(simBatch1) rm(simBatch2)

title: Loading a simulation and accessing entities
text: general, every workflow starts loading simulation calling loadSimulation() function. function receives full path *.pkml file format exported PK-Sim MoBi, returns corresponding simulation object.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)

what: Accessing entities of the model and their properties - the path concept
title: Loading a simulation and accessing entities
text: simulation loaded, possible retrieve various entities model. important entities containers, molecules, parameters. methods getContainer, getMolecule, getParameter search respective entity given path located container. path string elements path (.e., containers hierarchy simulation) separated |. container instance Container-class within model structure path relative . cases, container Simulation object created calling loadSimulation(pkmlSimulationFile). functions getAllContainersMatching(), getAllMoleculesMatching(), getAllParametersMatching() return list objects representing entities whose paths match generic paths provided list paths located container. Generic paths constructed using wildcard symbols * (exactly one occurrence element) ** (zero occurrences element). Note path "Organism|Kidney|*|Intracellular|Volume" return parameters standard models, sub-containers Kidney Intracellular. contrast, "Organism|Kidney|**|Intracellular|Volume" valid path. functions getAllContainersMatching(), getAllMoleculesMatching(), getAllParametersMatching() can also used retrieve entities multiple paths: entities possess various properties can accessed objects. important properties container : important properties molecule : important properties parameter :
code: # Get the molecule Aciclovir located in kidney intracellular space moleculeInKid <- getMolecule("Organism|Kidney|Intracellular|Aciclovir", sim) print(moleculeInKid) #> Molecule:  #>    Path: Organism|Kidney|Intracellular|Aciclovir  #>    Initial Value: 0.00 [µmol]  # Get the container "Liver" livContainer <- getContainer("Organism|Liver", sim) print(livContainer) #> Container:  #>    Container type: Organ  #>    Path: Organism|Liver  # Get the parameter volume of the liver interstitial space # Note that the path used is relative to the liver container livParam <- getParameter("Interstitial|Volume", livContainer) print(livParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume  #>    Value: 0.35 [l]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V  #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE # Get the parameter `Volume` of the intracellular space of all organs, # with exactly one path element before `Intracellular` volumeParams <- getAllParametersMatching("Organism|*|Intracellular|Volume", sim) length(volumeParams) #> [1] 15 # The PBPK model has 15 organs with an "Intracellular" sub-compartment  # Get the parameter `Volume` of the intracellular space of all organs, # no matter how many sub-containers the organ has volumeParams <- getAllParametersMatching("Organism|**|Intracellular|Volume", sim) length(volumeParams) #> [1] 28 # The list also includes parameters of organs like "Liver|Periportal", # or the mucosal compartments of the intestine. # Get the molecule Aciclovir located in `Liver|Periportal|Intracellular` and `VenousBlood|Plasma` molecules <- getAllMoleculesMatching(c(   "Organism|VenousBlood|Plasma|Aciclovir",   "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir" ), sim) print(molecules) #> [[1]] #> Molecule:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir  #>    Initial Value: 0.00 [µmol]  #>  #> [[2]] #> Molecule:  #>    Path: Organism|VenousBlood|Plasma|Aciclovir  #>    Initial Value: 0.00 [µmol] # Path of the container livContainer$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver"  # Parent container livContainer$parentContainer #> Container:  #>    Container type: Organism  #>    Path: Organism # Initial value of the molecule moleculeInKid$value #> [1] 0  # Dimension of the molecule. See section "Unit conversion" for more information. moleculeInKid$dimension #> [1] "Amount"  # Is the initial value defined by a formula? moleculeInKid$isFormula #> [1] FALSE  # Type of the formula. CONSTANT if the value is defined by a constant. moleculeInKid$formula #> Formula:  #>    isConstant: TRUE # Initial value of the parameter livParam$value #> [1] 0.3533005  # Dimension of the parameter. See section "Unit conversion" for more information. livParam$dimension #> [1] "Volume"  # Base unit of the parameter. See section "Unit conversion" for more information. livParam$unit #> [1] "l"  # Is the initial value defined by a formula? livParam$isFormula #> [1] TRUE  # Type of the formula. CONSTANT if the value is defined by a constant. livParam$formula #> Formula:  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V

title: Loading a simulation and accessing entities
text: convenient way traverse simulation structure given method getSimulationTree. method generates tree-like list paths within simulation. element tree contains sub-containers element. final elements strings representing path entity.
code: # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Create simulation tree simTree <- getSimulationTree(sim)  # Calling simTree would list all entities within the simulation # (given how long this tree can be, we will skip it here, but you can try # running the following command in your console) # simTree  # Accessing the parameter "Organism|Weight" simTree$Organism$Weight #> $path #> [1] "Organism|Weight"  # Getting all entities located under "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular" entitiesList <- simTree$Organism$Liver$Periportal$Intracellular entitiesList #> $`Volume of protein container` #> $`Volume of protein container`$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Volume of protein container" #>  #>  #> $Volume #> $Volume$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Volume" #>  #>  #> $pH #> $pH$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|pH" #>  #>  #> $Aciclovir #> $Aciclovir$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir" #>  #> $Aciclovir$Concentration #> $Aciclovir$Concentration$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir|Concentration" #>  #>  #> $Aciclovir$`Partition coefficient (water/container)` #> $Aciclovir$`Partition coefficient (water/container)`$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir|Partition coefficient (water/container)" #>  #>  #> $Aciclovir$`Concentration in container` #> $Aciclovir$`Concentration in container`$path #> [1] "Organism|Liver|Periportal|Intracellular|Aciclovir|Concentration in container"

title: Introduction to ospsuite
text: order load simulation R, must present *.pkml file format. Every simulation PK-Sim MoBi can exported *.pkml file. Unless otherwise stated, examples shown vignettes based Aciclovir example model. model can found PK-Sim examples folder OSPS installation. general workflow ospsuite package can summarized following steps: Loading simulation .pkml file. Accessing entities simulation, molecules, parameters, containers, reading information . Changing simulation settings, parameter values, molecules start values. Retrieving results processing . workflow steps described following vignettes: Loading simulation accessing entities Changing parameter molecule start values Running simulation Efficient calculations Creating individuals Population simulations PK Analysis Sensitivity analysis Table parameters Dimensions Units aspects ospsuite package may appear uncommon users familiar object-oriented approach. recommended read following section better understand semantics get flexibility efficiency package.

title: Introduction to ospsuite
text: ospsuite R-package utilizes concept object oriented (OO) programming based R6 system. philosophy package offer functional programming workflow common R users, important understand basic concepts OO programming. functions implemented ospsuite return instance (object) class. objects can used inputs functions. Additionally, object offers set properties (can objects) functions, accessible $ sign: Important information object can printed calling print(object). important classes : Simulation Representation simulation loaded *.pkml file. SimulationRunOptions object defining options simulation run. options : numberOfCores maximal number (logical) cores can used (population) simulation; checkForNegativeValues boolean defining error thrown variables become negative "negativeValuesAllowed"-flag set FALSE (can used ignore numerical noise); showProgress Boolean “progress bar” shown console representing progress simulation. SolverSettings Object defining settings solver. Stored SimulationSettings Simulation (accessibly field $settings). OutputSchema Definition output intervals simulation. OutputSchema defines total simulation time time points results generated. Can accessed property Simulation-object. OutputSelections List quantities (parameters molecules) outputs generated. Can accessed property Simulation-object. SimulationResults Results simulation, either individual population. Holds simulated values quantities defined OutputSelections. See Running simulation information. Entity Every accessible distinct part model. prominent entities Molecule, Parameter, Container. Every Entity properties $path representing path within model structure $parentContainer container entity located . Container Container element model structure contains entities (e.g., spatial containers, molecules, parameters). prominent containers organs compartments. loaded Simulation also container. Quantity Entity simulation value - namely Molecule Parameter. Every Quantity $value $dimension. important fields $unit, base unit dimension. See Dimensions Units information. Molecule molecule located Container. $value-property refers initial value simulation. Inherits Quantity. Parameter parameter. $value-property refers initial value simulation. Inherits Quantity. Formula value Quantity described $formula-property. different types formulae, see Changing parameter molecule start values information. IndividualCharacteristics object used creating individual parameter sets createIndividual-method. See Creating individuals information. Population object describing virtual population. Can either loaded *.csv-file created PK-Sim created createPopulation-method. See Population simulations information. PopulationCharacteristics object used creating population parameter sets createPopulation-method. See Population simulations information. SimulationPKAnalyses PK analyses simulations result. QuantityPKParameter certain PK parameter output quantity. fields $name name PK parameter (e.g. “C_max”), $quantityPath path output parameter calculated , $values value (list values population simulation). SensitivityAnalysis class defining analysis input parameters impact output curves simulation. See Sensitivity analysis information. SensitivityAnalysisResults Results running SensitivityAnalysis PKParameterSensitivity sensitivity (field $value) PK-Parameter ($pkParameterName) output $outputPath calculated varied parameter $parameterName. See Sensitivity analysis information.
code: object1           <- ClassName$new() aProperty         <- object1$property1 resultOfAFunction <- object1$multiply(1,2)

title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
text: ospsuite package gives access standard PK Parameters calculated PK-Sim AUC, Cmax etc. complete list PK Parameters supported box, please refer online documentaton. PK parameters can calculated outputs simulation. First, simulation results must calculated, SimulationResults object passed method calculatePKAnalyses. list calculated PK parameters description, please refer OSPS documentation. function calculatePKAnalyses returns object class SimulationPKAnalyses, allows retrieve either certain PK parameter output path, calculated PK parameters output path. methods $allPKParametersFor() $pKParameterFor() return object (list objects) class QuantityPKParameter, fields $name name pk-parameter (e.g. “C_max”), $quantityPath path output parameter calculated , $values value (list values population simulation). case population simulation, $values return list values calculated individual.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # Load the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Run the simulation simulationResults <- runSimulation(simulation = sim)  # Calculate PK-analyses pkAnalysis <- calculatePKAnalyses(results = simulationResults)  # Get the path of the simulated output outputPath <- simulationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(outputPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  # Get all calculated PK parameters for the output path allPkParams <- pkAnalysis$allPKParametersFor(outputPath) print(allPkParams) #> [[1]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): C_max  #>    Dimension: Concentration (molar)  #>    Unit: µmol/l  #>  #> [[2]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): C_max_norm  #>    Dimension: Concentration (mass)  #>    Unit: kg/l  #>  #> [[3]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): t_max  #>    Dimension: Time  #>    Unit: min  #>  #> [[4]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): C_tEnd  #>    Dimension: Concentration (molar)  #>    Unit: µmol/l  #>  #> [[5]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): AUC_tEnd  #>    Dimension: AUC (molar)  #>    Unit: µmol*min/l  #>  #> [[6]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): AUC_tEnd_norm  #>    Dimension: AUC (mass)  #>    Unit: kg*min/l  #>  #> [[7]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): AUC_inf  #>    Dimension: AUC (molar)  #>    Unit: µmol*min/l  #>  #> [[8]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): AUC_inf_norm  #>    Dimension: AUC (mass)  #>    Unit: kg*min/l  #>  #> [[9]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): MRT  #>    Dimension: Time  #>    Unit: min  #>  #> [[10]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): Thalf  #>    Dimension: Time  #>    Unit: min  #>  #> [[11]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): FractionAucLastToInf  #>    Dimension: Fraction  #>    Unit:   #>  #> [[12]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): CL  #>    Dimension: Flow per weight  #>    Unit: l/min/kg  #>  #> [[13]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): Vss  #>    Dimension: Volume per body weight  #>    Unit: l/kg  #>  #> [[14]] #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): Vd  #>    Dimension: Volume per body weight  #>    Unit: l/kg  # Get C_max parameter c_max <- pkAnalysis$pKParameterFor(quantityPath = outputPath, pkParameter = "C_max") c_max #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): C_max  #>    Dimension: Concentration (molar)  #>    Unit: µmol/l # Get C_max parameter c_max <- pkAnalysis$pKParameterFor(quantityPath = outputPath, pkParameter = "C_max")  print(c_max) #> QuantityPKParameter:  #>    Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood): C_max  #>    Dimension: Concentration (molar)  #>    Unit: µmol/l  c_max$name #> [1] "C_max" c_max$quantityPath #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)" c_max$values #> [1] 50.25272

title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
text: Population analysis calculated R can exported *.csv file loaded PK-Sim, vice versa.
code: # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) simulationResults <- runSimulation(simulation = sim)  # Calculate PK-analysis pkAnalysis <- calculatePKAnalyses(results = simulationResults)  # Export to csv csvPKAnalysisPath <- system.file("extdata", "PKAnalyses.csv", package = "ospsuite") exportPKAnalysesToCSV(pkAnalyses = pkAnalysis, filePath = csvPKAnalysisPath)  # Load from csv pkAnalysisLoaded <- importPKAnalysesFromCSV(filePath = csvPKAnalysisPath, simulation = sim)

title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
text: ospsuite package also supports user-defined PK Parameters, e.g. PK Parameter can tailored specific project needs. feature useful calculating PK Parameters specific time intervals, apply PK Parameters output using dimension Concentration. User-Defined PK Parameter always based existing PK-Parameter simply extends way output calcualted. possible moment define formula. utility addUserDefinedPKParameter creates returns instance UserDefinedPKParameter can parameterized specific requirements.

what: Calculate AUC between for a specific time interval.
title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
code: # Adds a user defined parameter named `MyAuc` that will calculate the value of AUC between t=50 min and t=80min only.  # Create a new parameter based on the standard AUC parameter myAUC <- addUserDefinedPKParameter(   name = "MyAUC",   standardPKParameter = StandardPKParameter$AUC_tEnd )  # Specifies start time and end time in minute myAUC$startTime <- 50 myAUC$endTime <- 80

what: Calculate CMax between the 4th and 5th application of a multiple applications simulation.
title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
code: # Adds a user defined parameter named `MyCMax` that will calculate the value of Cmax between the 4th and 5th application  # Create a new parameter based on the standard C_max parameter myCMax <- addUserDefinedPKParameter(   name = "MyCMax",   standardPKParameter = StandardPKParameter$C_max )  # Specifies start application (4th) and end applicaiton (5th) myCMax$startApplicationIndex <- 4 myCMax$endApplicationIndex <- 5

what: Calculate CMax between the 4th and 5th application of a multiple applications simulation and apply a time offset
title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
code: # Adds a user defined parameter named `MyCMax` that will calculate the value of Cmax between the 4th application start time + 10 min and # the 5th application start time + 20min  # Create a new parameter based on the standard C_max parameter myCMax <- addUserDefinedPKParameter(   name = "MyCMax",   standardPKParameter = StandardPKParameter$C_max )  # Specifies start application (4th) and end applicaiton (5th) myCMax$startApplicationIndex <- 4 myCMax$endApplicationIndex <- 5  # Specifies start time offset. The PK calculations wil effectively start at StartTime of 4th Application + 10 min myCMax$startTimeOffset <- 10  # Specifies end time offset . The PK calculations wil effectively ends at StartTime of 5th Application + 20 min myCMax$endTimeOffset <- 20

what: Update Dimension of a standard parameter for correct visualization
title: Calculating PK parameters of simulation outputs
text: PK parameters currently always assume underlying quantity concentration check units. quantity interest another dimension, creating user-defined PK parameter setting display unit valid unit target dimension can trick happen : dimension user defined PK PArameter estimated display unit, e.g case mg/m² calculated value user defined PK Parameter interpreted value base unit dimension, e.g. “kg/dm²” display unit differs base unit dimension, calculated value converted target display unit E.g. example : First, C_max value quantity calculated (user defined parameter derived C_max) display unit mg/m², dimension estimated (“Dose per body surface area”) calculated C_max value interpreted value kg/dm² Finally, calculated value converted mg/m² set user defined PK Parameter. see options user defined PK Parameter, refer documentation UserDefinedPKParameter (?UserDefinedPKParameter RStudio)
code: # Let's assume there is an observer called Q_observer in mg/m2 using the dimension Dose per body surface area. # Simply using C_max would result in the parameter being shown in umol\l. # To see the correct unit and dimension, the following can be done:  QMax <- addUserDefinedPKParameter(   name = "Q_max",   standardPKParameter = StandardPKParameter$C_max,   displayName = "Q max",   displayUnit = "mg/m²" )

what: Running individual simulation and retrieving the results
title: Running a simulation
text: simulation loaded (see Loading simulation accessing entities), can run using runSimulations() produce object class SimulationResults. Keep mind runSimulations() produces list SimulationResults objects. advantage storing results object option keep different results simulation produced different settings (e.g., model parameters). Simulated time-value pairs specific output SimulationResults-object can accessed method getOutputValues. user can provide either path(s) output (can molecule, parameter, observer), object(s) type Molecule, Parameter, Quantity (observers) argument quantitiesOrPaths. output specified, outputs available simulation results returned. paths available outputs can accessed via getOutputValues returns list two entries: data metadata: data dataframe two predefined columns (IndividualId Time) well one column requested output IndividualId (relevant individual simulation) Time vector simulated time values (minutes, equal outputs) vector simulated entries output requested. metaData list containing one entry requested output. entry contains information pertinent output dimension unit.  results can stored imported *.csv file methods exportResultsToCSV importResultsFromCSV.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # Load the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  simulationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = sim) # Extract `SimulationResults` by simulation id simulationResults <- simulationResults[[sim$id]] print(simulationResults) #> SimulationResults:  #>    Number of individuals: 1 simulationResults$allQuantityPaths #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)" # Get simulated results by path resultsPath <- simulationResults$allQuantityPaths[[1]] print(resultsPath) #> [1] "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)"  resultsData <- getOutputValues(simulationResults, quantitiesOrPaths = resultsPath)  resultsTime <- resultsData$data$Time resultsValues <- resultsData$data$`Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)`  plot(resultsTime, resultsValues, type = "l") # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) # `runSimulations` returns a list of `SimulationResults`. For single simulation, # we directly extract the first element, as only one object is created. simulationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)[[1]]  # Export to csv csvResultsPath <- system.file("extdata", "SimResults.csv", package = "ospsuite") exportResultsToCSV(results = simulationResults, filePath = csvResultsPath)  # Load from csv resultsLoaded <- importResultsFromCSV(filePaths = csvResultsPath, simulation = sim) print(resultsLoaded) #> SimulationResults:  #>    Number of individuals: 1

what: Running multiple individual simulations and retrieving the results
title: Running a simulation
text: cases, user might want run multiple simulations parallel. can achieved easily simply passing list simulations runSimulations() function. However, individual simulations (.e., population argument must remain empty) supported. default, simulations executed parallel using cores available machine minus 1. 8 cores user simulates 4 simulations, 4 cores used. hand, user simulates 10 simulations 8 cores available, 7 used first 3 available. results case named list SimulationResults-object , .e. one simulation. names entries list ids simulation results correspond. way, easy retrieve correct results specific simulation
code: # Load and run multiple simulations concurrently. simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  # We load 3 times the same simulation for convenience. But in real life scenarios, # they should be different simulations sim1 <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) sim2 <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) sim3 <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  simulationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = list(sim1, sim2, sim3)) # Get the id of the second simulation id <- sim2$id print(id) #> [1] "SI-BgrlYNkuj-6kEcAMatQ" # get the corresponding result sim2Results <- simulationResults[[id]] print(sim2Results$simulation$id) #> [1] "SI-BgrlYNkuj-6kEcAMatQ"

title: Running a simulation
text: default, outputs selected PK-Sim MoBi prior export simulation pkml generated. user can add new outputs simulation method addOutputs. outputs can provided either objects type(s) Molecule, Parameter, Quantity, path strings. output list property simulation. adding removing outputs, corresponding simulation needs re-run order generate updated results.
code: # Clear the list of generated outputs clearOutputs(sim)  # Add new outputs as objects molecule <- getMolecule("Organism|Kidney|Intracellular|Aciclovir", sim) observer <- getQuantity("Organism|Lumen|Aciclovir|Fraction dissolved", sim)  addOutputs(c(molecule, observer), simulation = sim)  # Add new outputs as path strings addOutputs(c(   "Organism|Lumen|Stomach|Aciclovir",   "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Whole Blood (Peripheral Venous Blood)" ), simulation = sim )  # Run simulation simulationResults <- runSimulations(simulations = sim)  # Retrieve all generated outputs (e.g. omitting the quantitiesOrPaths property # will return all available values) resultsData <- getOutputValues(simulationResults)  # Note that "Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)" # is not in the list of generated results any more names(resultsData$data) #> NULL

title: Running a simulation
text: simulation interval (.e., simulation times results stored) stored property $outputSchema Simulation object. change simulation interval, user can use one functions clearOutputIntervals(), addOutputInterval(), setOutputInterval().
code: print(sim$outputSchema) #> OutputSchema:  #> Interval:  #>    Name: Simulation interval high resolution  #>    Start time: 0.00 [min]  #>    End time: 15.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 1.00 [pts/min]  #> Interval:  #>    Name: Simulation Interval 1  #>    Start time: 15.00 [min]  #>    End time: 1440.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 0.33 [pts/min]  #> Interval:  #>    Name: Simulation Interval 2  #>    Start time: 120.00 [min]  #>    End time: 1440.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 0.07 [pts/min] # Remove all output intervals - simulation not possible! clearOutputIntervals(simulation = sim) runSimulations(simulations = sim) #> Error in rClr::clrCall(simulationRunner, "Run", simulationRunArgs): Type:    OSPSuite.Utility.Exceptions.OSPSuiteException #> Message: Time points output schema is empty #> Method:  Void RunSimulation() #> Stack trace: #>    at OSPSuite.SimModel.Simulation.RunSimulation() #>    at OSPSuite.Core.Domain.Services.SimModelManager.simulate() #>    at OSPSuite.Core.Domain.Services.SimModelManager.doIfNotCanceled(Action actionToExecute) #>    at OSPSuite.Core.Domain.Services.SimModelManager.RunSimulation(IModelCoreSimulation simulation, SimulationRunOptions simulationRunOptions) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Services.SimulationRunner.run(IModelCoreSimulation simulation, SimulationRunOptions simulationRunOptions) #>    at OSPSuite.R.Services.SimulationRunner.Run(SimulationRunArgs simulationRunArgs)  # Add an interval addOutputInterval(simulation = sim, startTime = 0, endTime = 20, resolution = 60, intervalName = "highRes") print(sim$outputSchema) #> OutputSchema:  #> Interval:  #>    Name: highRes  #>    Start time: 0.00 [min]  #>    End time: 20.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 60.00 [pts/min]  # Add a second interval addOutputInterval(simulation = sim, startTime = 30, endTime = 2000, resolution = 4, intervalName = "lowRes") print(sim$outputSchema) #> OutputSchema:  #> Interval:  #>    Name: highRes  #>    Start time: 0.00 [min]  #>    End time: 20.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 60.00 [pts/min]  #> Interval:  #>    Name: lowRes  #>    Start time: 30.00 [min]  #>    End time: 2000.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 4.00 [pts/min]  # Replace the existing interval(s) with a new one setOutputInterval(simulation = sim, startTime = 0, endTime = 2000, resolution = 4) print(sim$outputSchema) #> OutputSchema:  #> Interval:  #>    Name: Output interval  #>    Start time: 0.00 [min]  #>    End time: 2000.00 [min]  #>    Resolution: 4.00 [pts/min]

title: Sensitivity analysis
text: first step performing sensitivity analysis creating object class SensitivityAnalysis. step, user can define parameters considered sensitivity analysis, range values varied, may steps performed one direction (plus minus). parameters specified, constant suitable sensitivity calculations parameters simulation variated. list parameters paths simulation can accessed method potentialVariableParameterPathsFor(simulation). New parameters can added existing SensitivityAnalysis calling method addParameterPaths(). NOTE: - parameters specified creation SensitivityAnalysis, constant suitable sensitivity calculation parameters considered. - cases, calling addParameterPaths() vary newly added parameters. run specified SensitivityAnalysis, call method runSensitivityAnalysis(). method returns object class SensitivityAnalysisResults. impact defined parameters calculated PK-Parameters (see PK Analysis information) model outputs. method allPKParameterSensitivitiesFor() returns list PKParameterSensitivity objects. PKParameterSensitivity describes sensitivity (field $value) PK-Parameter ($pkParameterName) output $outputPath calculated varied parameter $parameterPath. argument totalSensitivityThreshold method allPKParameterSensitivitiesFor() used filter impactful parameters. threshold 0.9 means parameters participating total 90 percent sensitivity returned. value 1 return sensitivity parameters. value provided, default value used. value -1 sensitivity “AUC_inf” output Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood) parameter Organism-Kidney-Volume means increasing Organism-Kidney-Volume 10% decrease “AUC_inf” 10%. Note list sensitivities ordered largest smallest respect magnitude.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "simple.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Get the paths of parameters that will be considered by default. potentialSAParameters <- potentialVariableParameterPathsFor(sim) print(potentialSAParameters) #> [1] "Organism|Volume" "Organism|Q"      "R1|k1"  # Create a default `SensitivityAnalysis` for the simulation sa <- SensitivityAnalysis$new(simulation = sim) print(sa) #> SensitivityAnalysis:  #>    Number of steps: 2  #>    Variation range: 0.1  #>    Number of parameters to vary: Will be estimated at run time  # Create a `SensitivityAnalysis` with specified parameters sa <- SensitivityAnalysis$new(simulation = sim, parameterPaths = c("Organism|Q", "Organism|Volume")) print(sa) #> SensitivityAnalysis:  #>    Number of steps: 2  #>    Variation range: 0.1  #>    Number of parameters to vary: 2  # Show which parameters will be varied sa$parameterPaths #> [1] "Organism|Q"      "Organism|Volume" library(ospsuite)  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "simple.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Create a `SensitivityAnalysis` with specified parameters sa <- SensitivityAnalysis$new(simulation = sim, parameterPaths = c(   "Organism|Q",   "Organism|Volume" )) # Add new parameter sa$addParameterPaths("R1|k1")  # Show which parameters will be varied sa$parameterPaths #> [1] "Organism|Q"      "Organism|Volume" "R1|k1" # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "simple.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Create a `SensitivityAnalysis` with all constant and suitable for sensitivity calculations parameters and suitable for sensitivity calculations parameters sa <- SensitivityAnalysis$new(simulation = sim)  # Run the sensitivity analysis saResult <- runSensitivityAnalysis(sa) print(saResult) #> SensitivityAnalysisResults:  #>    Number of calculated sensitivities: 72  #>    Available PK parameters: C_max t_max C_tEnd AUC_tEnd Thalf AUC_inf MRT FractionAucLastToInf # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Default value of the threshold getOSPSuiteSetting("sensitivityAnalysisConfig")$totalSensitivityThreshold #> [1] 0.9  # Create a `SensitivityAnalysis` with all constant parameters and run it sa <- SensitivityAnalysis$new(   simulation = sim,   parameterPaths = c(     "Aciclovir|Lipophilicity",     "Aciclovir|Fraction unbound (plasma)",     "Organism|Age"   ) ) saResult <- runSensitivityAnalysis(sa) print(saResult) #> SensitivityAnalysisResults:  #>    Number of calculated sensitivities: 11  #>    Available PK parameters: C_max t_max C_tEnd AUC_tEnd AUC_inf MRT Thalf FractionAucLastToInf CL Vss Vd  # Get sensitivities for the parameter "AUC_inf" of the simulated output with a threshold of 0.8 outputPath <- sim$outputSelections$allOutputs[[1]]$path sensitivities <- saResult$allPKParameterSensitivitiesFor(pkParameterName = "AUC_inf", outputPath = outputPath, totalSensitivityThreshold = 0.8) print(sensitivities) #> [[1]] #> PKParameterSensitivity:  #>    Parameter name: Aciclovir-Lipophilicity  #>    PK-Parameter: AUC_inf  #>    Output path: Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)  #>    Value: 0.00470852808265833

what: Import and export of sensitivity analysis results
title: Sensitivity analysis
text: Sensitivity analysis calculated R can exported *.csv file, can loaded another instance.
code: # Load and run the simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "simple.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath) simulationResults <- runSimulation(simulation = sim)  # Create a `SensitivityAnalysis` with all constant parameters and run it sa <- SensitivityAnalysis$new(simulation = sim) saResult <- runSensitivityAnalysis(sa)  # Export to csv saResultPath <- system.file("extdata", "SAResult.csv", package = "ospsuite") exportSensitivityAnalysisResultsToCSV(results = saResult, filePath = saResultPath)  # Load from csv saResultLoaded <- importSensitivityAnalysisResultsFromCSV(filePaths = saResultPath, simulation = sim)

title: Changing parameter and molecule start values
text: possible change initial values parameters molecules simulation. important differentiate constant values values defined formula.

title: Changing parameter and molecule start values
text: Every (initial) value described either constant formula. value defined simple constant, field isConstant respective parameter molecule value TRUE. value constant, described one formula types: Distributed: Distributed parameters describe variation around constant value two numerical limits. simulation, behavior equals constant values. See OSPS documentation information. Explicit formula: value parameter given explicit formula. value explicit formula can change simulation. string formula can accessed via parameter$formulaString. Table formula: value parameter given table x-y value pairs. X values usually refer simulation time. See Table parameters additional information retrieve change table values. Additionally, parameters modeled state variables. case, parameter initial value right hand side (RHS) formula, can formula type.
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # Load simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Get the parameter "Age" of the Organism ageParam <- getParameter("Organism|Age", sim) print(ageParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Age  #>    Value: 25.70 [year(s)]  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE ageParam$isConstant #> [1] TRUE # Get the parameter "Volume" of the Liver liverVolume <- getParameter("Organism|Liver|Volume", sim) print(liverVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Volume  #>    Value: 2.17 [l]  #>    isDistributed: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE liverVolume$isDistributed #> [1] TRUE # Get the parameter "Volume" of the Liver interstital liverIntVolume <- getParameter("Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume", sim) print(liverIntVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume  #>    Value: 0.35 [l]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V  #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE liverIntVolume$formulaString #> [1] "f_int*V" # Get the parameter defined by a table. tableParam <- getParameter("Organism|TableParameter", sim) print(tableParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 0.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 0, y= 0, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE # Get the parameter defined by a state variable. stateVariableParam <- getParameter("Organism|StateVariable_Parameter", sim) print(stateVariableParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|StateVariable_Parameter  #>    Value: 0.00  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: TRUE  #>    RHSFormula:  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: Time * 2  # `value` refers to the initial value of the parameter stateVariableParam$value #> [1] 0 # `rhsFormula` is the right hand side of the parameter stateVariableParam$rhsFormula #> Formula:  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: Time * 2

what: Changing parameters and molecules initial values
title: Changing parameter and molecule start values
text: user can change initial values parameters molecules methods setParameterValues setMoleculeInitialValues, respectively. Another way change parameter values scale . scaling always performed relative current value: constant values can set. parameters value defined formula (explicit table), newly assigned value override formula. reflected field isFixedValue. Changing values formula parameters done caution, potential dependency another simulation parameters destroyed. parameter value can reset formula assigning constant value: Changing value state variable parameter change initial value, right hand side (.e., value simulation still change according RHS formula). switch RHS formula , , make parameter dependent initial value, field isStateVariable can set FALSE. function one-way ! possible re-activate RHS formula switching . example set initial values molecules containers certain value:
code: # Get the parameter Dose doseParamPath <- "Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose" doseParam <- getParameter(doseParamPath, sim) print(doseParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose  #>    Value: 0.00 [kg]  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Change the dose to 350mg. The value has to be converted to base unit, first newValue <- toBaseUnit(quantity = doseParam, values = 350, unit = "mg") setParameterValues(parameters = doseParam, values = newValue) print(doseParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose  #>    Value: 0.00 [kg]  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE doseParamPath <- "Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose" doseParam <- getParameter(doseParamPath, sim) print(doseParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose  #>    Value: 0.00 [kg]  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Double the dose scaleParameterValues(doseParam, factor = 2) print(doseParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose  #>    Value: 0.00 [kg]  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Half the dose scaleParameterValues(doseParam, factor = 0.5) print(doseParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose  #>    Value: 0.00 [kg]  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE # Get the parameter "Volume" of the Liver interstital liverIntVolume <- getParameter("Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume", sim) print(liverIntVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume  #>    Value: 0.35 [l]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V  #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # isFixedValue is FALSE as the parameter is defined by its formula liverIntVolume$isFixedValue #> [1] FALSE  setParameterValues(liverIntVolume, 1) print(liverIntVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume  #>    Value: 1.00 [l]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V  #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE # isFixedValue is TRUE as the value of parameter is overridden by the constant value liverIntVolume$isFixedValue #> [1] TRUE print(liverIntVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume  #>    Value: 1.00 [l]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V  #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # isFixedValue is TRUE as the value of parameter is overridden by the constant value liverIntVolume$isFixedValue #> [1] TRUE  liverIntVolume$reset() print(liverIntVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Interstitial|Volume  #>    Value: 0.35 [l]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: f_int*V  #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE liverIntVolume$isFixedValue #> [1] FALSE # Get the parameter defined by a state variable. stateVariableParam <- getParameter("Organism|StateVariable_Parameter", sim) print(stateVariableParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|StateVariable_Parameter  #>    Value: 0.00  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: TRUE  #>    RHSFormula:  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: Time * 2  # Setting its value only changes the initial value setParameterValues(stateVariableParam, 10) print(stateVariableParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|StateVariable_Parameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: TRUE  #>    RHSFormula:  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: Time * 2  # Switching the RHS formula off stateVariableParam$isStateVariable <- FALSE print(stateVariableParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|StateVariable_Parameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isConstant: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Switching it on is not supported stateVariableParam$isStateVariable <- TRUE #> Error: Creating a RHS Formula is not supported at the moment. This should be done in MoBi. # Get objects representing the molecule Aciclovir in all containers allAciclovirMolecules <- getAllMoleculesMatching("Organism|**|Aciclovir", sim)  # Set initial values to 10 µmol in all containers setMoleculeInitialValues(allAciclovirMolecules, rep(10, length(allAciclovirMolecules)))

title: Table parameters
text: Simply setting value table-defined parameter using setParameterValues override formula make parameter constant. change values table, set methods TableFormula available. method addPoints() adds set x-y values existing table. trying add point x-value already present table, error thrown: remove point table, use method removePoint(). remove point x value present table provided y. clearPoints() method removes points table, setPoints() method combination clearing table adding new points:
code: # Get the parameter defined by a table. tableParam <- getParameter("Organism|TableParameter", sim) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 0.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 0, y= 0, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Set value to a constant. tableParam$isFixedValue is now TRUE setParameterValues(tableParam, 10) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 0, y= 0, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE tableParam <- getParameter("Organism|TableParameter", sim) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 0, y= 0, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Add new points tableParam$formula$addPoints(c(1, 2, 3), c(5, 6, 7)) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 0, y= 0, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Try to add points with existing x-values tableParam$formula$addPoints(0, 1) #> Error in rClr::clrCall(self$ref, "AddPoint", xValues[i], yValues[i]): Type:    OSPSuite.Core.Domain.ValuePointAlreadyExistsForPointException #> Message: A point for x=0 was already added with y=1 #> Method:  Int32 AddPoint(OSPSuite.Core.Domain.Formulas.ValuePoint) #> Stack trace: #>    at OSPSuite.Core.Domain.Formulas.TableFormula.AddPoint(ValuePoint point) #>    at OSPSuite.Core.Domain.Formulas.TableFormula.AddPoint(Double x, Double y) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 0, y= 0, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Remove the point (0, 0) tableParam$formula$removePoint(0, 0) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Try to remove the point (1, 1). Note that the value for x = 1 is x = 5 in the original table, # and no point is removed. tableParam$formula$removePoint(1, 1) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Try to remove a non-existing point (0, 1). No point is removed. tableParam$formula$removePoint(1, 1) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 60, y= 1, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 120, y= 2, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 180, y= 3, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  tableParam$formula$setPoints(c(1, 2, 3, 4), c(5, 6, 7, 8)) tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>   x= 1, y= 5, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 2, y= 6, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 3, y= 7, restartSolver= FALSE #>   x= 4, y= 8, restartSolver= FALSE #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  tableParam$formula$clearPoints() tableParam #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|TableParameter  #>    Value: 10.00  #>    isTable: TRUE  #>    XDimension: Time  #>    UseDerivedValues: FALSE  #>    Value overrides formula: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE

title: Dimensions and Units
text: Every entity - molecule, parameter, observer - certain dimension, like Amount, Concentration, Volume. dimension property entity: values certain dimension can presented different units - example, l ml dimension Volume, mol µmol dimension Amount. list available units entity can obtained using allUnits() method: Internally, OSPS works base units, values shown passed functions base units default. base units often different units displayed default PK-Sim (MoBi). list base default display units can found documentation. example, parameter BMI given default unit kg/dm², default display unit convenient kg/m². {ospuite} package provides set methods conversion different units. methods toUnit(), toBaseUnit(), toDisplayUnit() require quantity get correct dimension units; however, change value quantity!
code: library(ospsuite) #> Loading required package: rClr #> Loading the dynamic library for Microsoft .NET runtime... #> Loaded Common Language Runtime version 4.0.30319.42000  # Load a simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Get the parameter volume of the liver. livParam <- getParameter("Organism|Liver|Volume", sim) print(livParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Volume  #>    Value: 2.17 [l]  #>    isDistributed: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Dimension of the parameter livParam$dimension #> [1] "Volume" # Dimension of the parameter livParam$dimension #> [1] "Volume"  # Units of the parameter livParam$allUnits #> [1] "l"  "ml" "µl" # Get the BMI parameter bmiParam <- getParameter("Organism|BMI", sim) print(bmiParam) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|BMI  #>    Value: 0.23 [kg/dm²]  #>    isFormula: TRUE  #>    formula: Height>0 ? BW / (Height)^2 : 0  #>    Value overrides formula: FALSE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  # Print the base and the default display units bmiParam$unit #> [1] "kg/dm²" bmiParam$displayUnit #> [1] "kg/m²"  # Convert the value from the base into the default display unit toDisplayUnit(quantity = bmiParam, values = bmiParam$value) #> [1] 23.43633  # Convert the value to the base unit, that can be used. e.g. for setting new parameter value toBaseUnit(quantity = bmiParam, values = 30, unit = "kg/m²") #> [1] 0.3  liverVolume <- getParameter("Organism|Liver|Volume", sim) print(liverVolume) #> Parameter:  #>    Path: Organism|Liver|Volume  #>    Value: 2.17 [l]  #>    isDistributed: TRUE  #>    isStateVariable: FALSE  liverVolume$allUnits #> [1] "l"  "ml" "µl"  # Convert from base volume unit to µl toUnit(quantity = liverVolume, values = c(1, 2, 3, 4), targetUnit = "ml") #> [1] 1000 2000 3000 4000

title: R package to manipulate OSPSuite Models
text: general, every workflow starts loading simulation exported *.pkml format. method loadSimulation() returns corresponding simulation used input methods. user can change values parameters initial conditions, run simulation, retrieve simulated results. detailed description methods typical workflows can found vignettes. can see list vignettes available ospsuite calling open specific vignette, call
code: library(ospsuite)  # Load a simulation simFilePath <- system.file("extdata", "Aciclovir.pkml", package = "ospsuite") sim <- loadSimulation(simFilePath)  # Get the parameter "Dose" doseParamPath <- "Applications|IV 250mg 10min|Application_1|ProtocolSchemaItem|Dose" doseParam <- getParameter(doseParamPath, sim)  # Change the dose to 350mg. The values has to be converted to base unit, first newValue <- toBaseUnit(quantity = doseParam, values = 350, unit = "mg") setParameterValues(parameters = doseParam, values = newValue)  # Simulate simResults <- runSimulation(simulation = sim) # Retrieve the results simulatedValues <- getOutputValues(simulationResults = simResults)  # Plot time-concentration profile plot(simulatedValues$data$Time, simulatedValues$data$`Organism|PeripheralVenousBlood|Aciclovir|Plasma (Peripheral Venous Blood)`, type = "l", xlab = "Time [min]", ylab = "Concentration [µmol/l]") vignette(package = "ospsuite") # Insert the name of the vignette you want to view as the argument vignette("introduction-ospsuite")

Keep mind can also change setting specific projects.

code: simPath <- system.file("extdata", "simple.pkml", package = "ospsuite")  # Load the simulation sim <- loadSimulation(simPath, addToCache = FALSE, loadFromCache = FALSE)  # clears the previous output schema clearOutputIntervals(sim)  # Adds a new interval starting at 1h and ending at 10h with a resolution of 10 points per hour addOutputInterval(sim, 1 * 60, 10 * 60, 1 / 6)  # Adds another interval starting at 10h and ending at 17h with a resolution of 4 points per hour # and a specified name addOutputInterval(sim, 10 * 60, 17 * 60, 4 / 60, intervalName = "Second Interval")

code: # Adds a user defined parameter named MyAuc that will calculate the value of AUC # between t=50 min and t=80min myAUC <- addUserDefinedPKParameter(   name = "MyAUC",   standardPKParameter = StandardPKParameter$AUC_tEnd ) myAUC$startTime <- 50 myAUC$endTime <- 80  # Adds a user defined parameter named MyCMax that will calculate the value of Cmax # between the 4th and 5th application myCMax <- addUserDefinedPKParameter(   name = "MyCMax",   standardPKParameter = StandardPKParameter$C_max ) myCMax$startApplicationIndex <- 4 myCMax$endApplicationIndex <- 5

title: Plot configuration for OSP plots — DefaultPlotConfiguration
text: Aesthetic mappings describe groups mapped visual properties (color, shape, size, etc.) geometries included plot (e.g. point, line, ribbon, etc.). supported values property can seen using {tlf} lists: color, fill: tlf::ColorMaps shape: tlf::Shapes legend position: tlf::LegendPositions alignments: tlf::Alignments linetype: tlf::Linetypes example, parameters related color (titleColor, yAxisLabelTicksColor, etc.) accept palettes available ``tlf::ColorMaps(e.g.tlf::ColorMaps$ospDefault`). Note named lists, , therefore, want assign specific element list object's public field, extract element first. example, want specify legend position outside plot left bottom, following:   course, extracted element single value, can also atomic vector. example, want assign different line type group profile plot, assign vector line types.   number elements vector number groups, additional elements ignored.
